text: Think about the technologies and theories underlying your work, in what context and for what use were they created? How has that changed over time?
In what ways is your team representative of the communities impacted by this project?
What additional help would your team need to mitigate or repair these negative impacts?
What business problem(s) does this project intend to solve?
What technical problem(s) does this project intend to solve?
What are the motivations behind this project for you and your team?
What are some internal and external metrics for assessing if the project's intent is being met?
What has been the most challenging technical barrier to overcome in your project so far?
How does this project differ from what was done previously or what others are currently doing in the field?
What are some non-technical barriers you are facing in this project?
Outside of your work, have you seen any examples where technology did not do what was intended and had negative impacts?
What has been the most challenging non-technical barrier to over come in your project far?
Think long term, how do you anticipate this project will evolve in the future?
Where do you NOT intend your work to end up?
What are some mistakes made in prior development or deployments of this or a similar technology?
Of these negative impacts, which ones are of most concern to you?
Who are the immediate or direct stakeholders in this project?
Who are the indirect or delayed stakeholders in this project?
Which stakeholders are currently prioritized in your work?
What are the core needs and concerns of both direct and indirect stakeholders?
What equipment and/or material resources are needed for this project?
What data are you using in your work?
What are the expected outcomes of this project?
What kinds of skills or perspectives do team members working on this project have?
Are there historical, social, political, cultural or environmental factors that are influencing the needs of your stakeholders?
What kinds of skills or perspectives are the team members working on this project missing?
What additional skills or perspectives do you need to prevent or mitigate negative impacts in your work?
What are some utopian futures or use-cases of this technology/research?
What are some dystopian futures or use-cases of this technology/research?
What are some positive impacts this or a similar technology have already had? Who primarily benefited from them?
What skills or perspectives have you noticed are consistently missing in the tech industry?
How might lack of diversity affect the types of research questions or projects the tech industry engages in?
Have aspects of this or a similar technology been misused in the past?
Which stakeholders have the most decision-making power in how your project is designed or implemented?
Think about the specific context in which your technology will be implemented. Are there additional stakeholders to consider?
What are some key issues that need to be addressed immediately due to actual or potential negative impact?
What accessibility considerations are you attending to in this project?
What are some negative impacts this or a similar technology already had? Who was primarily affected by these impacts?
Which potential negative impacts, if any, are you actively trying to avoid in your work?
Of these potential negative impacts, which ones are preventable or mitigable?
What are some unavoidable tensions or trade-offs between your stakeholders' needs and concerns?
What are some agreed upon metrics for assessing impacts in your field?
In what ways are outcomes similar or different from impacts?
What are some regulations currently in place to mitigate or prevent negative impacts of technologies related to this project?
What are some tools or methods currently available to mitigate or prevent negative impacts of technologies related to this project?
What are some technical barriers you are facing in this project?
Are there any technical tools (such as methods, APIs, or data sets) that exist today that might help mitigate negative impacts of your technology?
What are some key lessons from past instances where the technologies or theories underlying your work had negative impacts?
Who might be some internal people, teams, advocates or business units you could engage with to prevent or mitigate negative impacts of your work?
How would preventing or mitigating negative impacts benefit yourself, business, and society?
What are some concrete and feasible actions you can take today to prevent negative impacts of your work?
What are some ideal or long-term actions you would like to take to prevent negative impacts of your work?
What are some potential negative impacts of your work? Who would be primarily harmed by them?
Of these potential negative impacts, which ones are reversible?
Of these potential negative impacts, which ones may be long-lasting or permanent?
Which stakeholders have the least decision-making power in how your project is designed or implemented?
Of the stakeholders with least decision-making power, which ones would be most impacted by your work?
Are there communities that historically or currently don't engage with THE TECHNOLOGIES related to your project? Which ones and why?
Are there communities that historically or currently don't engage with RESEARCH related to your project? Which ones and why?
Are there communities that lack skilling necessary to benefit from your project? If so, how might this be addressed?
What factors could influence the impact of your project in society?
Of these impact metrics, which ones could be improved upon and why?
Historically speaking, how representative of the communities affected by technology are researchers in your field?

We define stakeholders as any person, entity, organization, or community that currently has or has previously had a stake in the work that you do now, or will in the future. A stakeholder is anyone or anything that is/was/will be directly or indirectly impacted by the work, anyone who directly or indirectly influences the work (or has in the past/will in the future), or anyone who cares about your work (or has in the past/might in the future). What do you think of this definition?

We define an outcome as a direct or indirect consequence of a technology, process, or project, which can happen along various terms and context, but does not necessitate change nor does it carry the same weight or strength of effect as an impact. What do you think of this definition?
What are some of the key methods used in this project?
What kinds of computational resources are required for this project?
What social or environmental problem(s) does this project intend to address?
How does this project contribute to the landscape of technical and non-technical solutions to these problems?
Discussion card: When reflecting on outcomes vs. impact, do you think it is possible to have a successful project but ultimately cause negative impacts? Why?
Discussion card: What are some potential benefits of re-defining success so that it more closely aligns with the projects' impact?
What are the motivations behind this project for business stakeholders?
If applicable, how has this project been framed by your organization's communications team, as well as the media?
In your work so far, do you see any evidence that actual impacts are deviating from your intent? Any evidence that they may diverge in the future?
What corrective action plans do you have in place should your work result in negative impacts?
What are some tangible use-cases or research questions that might stem from this project?
What modifications have you made or plan to make to mitigate or repair these negative impacts?
What modifications have you made or plan to make in your project to prevent reinstantiation of prior negative impact?
Are there any stakeholders (now or in the future) who might not know they could be impacted by your work? Which ones?
Who determines which stakeholders your team deems top priority?
Are there any stakeholders that are under-prioritized and might need to be prioritized in your work? Which ones?
What are some overlaps between the needs and concerns of your stakeholders?

We define impact as the direct consequence of a technology, process, or project, operationalized in various domains (technical, scientific, business, society, environment, and others). It is broad and indicates what has changed because of a specific technology, process, or project. Impacts can be existing or potential, immediate or delayed, short-term or long term, intended or unintended, but they are characterized primarily by the significant strength of the consequence or change (it is felt, it leaves a mark). What do you think of this definition?
How does achieving the expected outcome(s) of your project correlate with or differ from the potential impacts of your project?
What about factors that may affect the way in which stakeholders will use or implement this technology?
What about factors that may affect the way your technology or project is designed or built?
How would including more diverse skills or perspectives benefit your project?
What barriers are you facing when trying to include more diverse skills or perspectives in your work?
How might lack of diversity hinder the development of technologies that positively impact under-prioritized communities and/or the environment?
What additional help would your team need to prevent negative impacts of your work?
What could be done by your organization to prevent or mitigate negative impacts of technology in society?
Of these regulations, which ones could be updated or improved upon?
Might any aspects of this project's capabilities require new regulations, policies, or best practices?
What, if any, are the political and legal implications of your project?
What are some established best practices to mitigate or prevent negative impacts in this or a similar technology?
How can previous mistakes be avoided within your work and your field of research more broadly?
How can you increase engagement with stakeholders that could be negatively impacted?
How can you learn more about the needs and concerns of stakeholders that could be negatively impacted?
How can your organization support your engagement stakeholders that could be negatively impacted?
What internal resources at your organization could you leverage to mitigate or prevent negative impacts of your work?
What external resources could you leverage to better understand potential negative impacts in your work?
Which external people or organizations might you consider engaging with to mitigate or prevent negative impacts of your work?
Who could your organization collaborate or partner with to mitigate or prevent negative impacts of your work?

Put care first: If we put care first and at the center of our efforts, we can move away from delivering solely for individual and commercial interests. Care lets us deliver for public health and the planet through compassion and reciprocity.
Earn trust: As more of our lives are connected, we need to create systems that earn trust with people. Products, services, and standards that can be open, resilient and promote citizen empowerment.
Empower collective agency: Empowering collective agency starts with radical inclusion of the most vulnerable. We should be creating a new civic commons by making economic opportunity for the many.
Reimagine public value: We can create new resources and standards that favour the civic commons and public health over commercial value and the success of the few.

Design for peoples rights: Design is a political act and its our responsibility to design for peoples rights. Privacy is not a luxury for those that can afford it. Privacy is a human right. We must create systems that remove the imbalance of power and instead promote equity and citizen empowerment.

Ensure fair and just oversight: Without fairness and justice we cannot have equity. Too often, the commons is shorthand for the majority. So we need to place mechanisms for fair and just oversight inside our design systems, so society can hold the powerful to account.

Redistribute the power of technology: The web is the greatest single distribution platform ever created. As a result, it has an outsized impact on everything, including causing harm to the most vulnerable and excluded. Design must seek to redistribute that power for citizen empowerment and equity.

Create compassion at scale: AI and automation are rapidly changing the world. But currently they're focused on commercial goals rather than societal needs. We have an opportunity to reshape AI and automation so they create equity and reinforce civic commons. People must be in control, always.

Design for regenerative action: The climate emergency is an existential threat to humanity. We need to shift narratives and focus away from abundance and scarcity to regeneration. We need sustainable and regenerative design and business models for society for public health, and for the planet.

Confront uncertainty: The issues we face are intertwined, complex and ever-shifting. We live in radical times. And radical times require radical solutions. Doing nothing only favors a deadly status quo: we must act boldly and defiantly.
How are you documenting the limitations of your datasets?
How well do your datasets represent the communities that will be impacted by your project? How do you know?
What mechanisms do you have in place to evaluate the appropriateness of your datasets?
What are some feedback mechanisms currently in place to capture stakeholders' concerns about your work?
